name: Kenyan Sand Boa
description: These are compact snakes with a small head, indistinct neck, and short tail. Coloration is typically black-yellow or black-orange, with a white to creamy belly.
image_alt: Kenyan sand boa, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 40–90 cm; weight 70–900 g (males are significantly smaller than females)
attractions: It spends most of its time in a shallow underground burrow, with only its head protruding, ambushing prey with a lightning strike. Like many desert creatures, it emerges at night when air temperatures are more bearable.
breeding: According to surviving records, one sand boa was at the zoo from 1974–1979, then not again until 2003, when representatives of the subspecies E. c. loveridgei arrived for the Africa Up Close pavilion.
